….that graph you referred to from House Dust Biology for Allergists, Acarologists and Mycologists, is the “The chemical composition (by percentages) of dried dust samples taken mainly from floors (after Davies 1958) “ However that graph shows that the majority of airborne dust is cotton particles. Limiting “dust” to particles less than 100um in size, only accounts for approximately 20% of particles (NIST, 2001) . So saying that >50% of 20% of all airborne particles is dead skin particles only means about 10% is chemically identifiable as “dead” skin.

A Micrometer is a precision measurement device, often in thousandths of an inch or hundredths of a millimeter. A micrometer(micro-meter) is unit of precision measurement,x10^-6 meters. Although these two words are spelled the same they are not pronounced the same and do not mean the same thing. You measure particle sizes in micrometers (or microns) but you don’t measure dust with a micrometer.

In terms of particle count, human cells are probably the largest component of dust, but take your own dust and examine it under a microscope.  By volume mine is mostly hair and fibers, especially in the bedroom where the comforter is constantly shedding fibers.  If you have a down feather comforter in a flannel covering then probably 80% of the dust in your bedroom is from this one source.  We replaced our down comforter with a synthetic one and our dust volume went to maybe 10% of the previous value.

I feel I must comment about your pronunciation of the word 'micrometer'.
When used to describe the unit of length it should be pronounced 'micro-METER'. When used to describe the instrument used to make fine measurements it should be pronounced Mi-CHROM-eter. (I hope you can see the difference), Same spelling, different meaning and different pronunciation to make that distinction.
By the way, the correct pronunciation of 'kilometer' is 'KIL-O-meter' and NOT 'kil-AHM-eter' as most people say (including you). The pronunciation is defined in the ISO standard that defines everything else in the meter system. Take a look. Unfortunately, the incorrect pronunciation has become so accepted it is what a Google search will yield as the correct pronunciation. We don't say 'cent-AHM-eter'; or 'mill-AHM-eter' so why is 'kil-AHM-eter' so prevalent? A question for a video?

I used to sell Kirby vacuum cleaners and one of the tactics we would use is to set it up in hand mode, and then put these clean cotton filter traps in the path of the suction tube to be able to clearly show anything that got sucked up. You would go to the person's bed, and say "Do you think this is clean?" and pass the vacuum over the sheets, and sure enough there would always be a small pile of dead skin on the filter. This was very fine and did not look like regular household dust.  What was interesting is that the color of the skin dust would vary depending on the amount of melanin the people living in that house had in their skin. So certainly, a lot gets trapped in our mattresses, which only makes sense (we wash our sheets not our mattresses)  and there are probably colonies of microorganisms living the mattress that feed off of it. Fun stuff.

Once it was established that our skin produces around 20 million skin cells per hour it was pretty obvious that the rate of losing those skin cells would also be around 20 million per hour. It simply has to be an equilibrium. You have to much production to loss and your skin will get thicker and denser which I believe is a medical condition. You have to little production to loss and you will over time lose your entire epidermis. In fact I will go as far as to say that the rate of production for the skin cells was likely established based on the rate of the skin cell loss. After all it is much easier to quantify the cells you lose than the cells that are actively produced in a living tissue. How would you even measure that without vivisection?

In the Catholic observation of Ash Wednesday, which marks the beginning of Lent, ash is applied on people’s foreheads in the shape of a cross. As this is applied, one of the common phrases uttered by a priest is, “Remember that you are dust, and to dust you shall return,” calling to mind God’s words to Adam in Genesis 3:19.

When Abraham talks to God in Genesis 18, asking him to spare Sodom, he says, “Behold, I have undertaken to speak to the Lord, I who am but dust and ashes.”

In summary, the Bible uses dust and ashes to refer to mankind’s humble origin, feeble composition, and temporal nature. More broadly, the terms are used to convey poverty, humiliation, and lowliness.

In the Old Testament, covering oneself in sackcloth and ashes conveyed sorrow, debasement, and repentance (2 Sam 13:19; Esther 4:1,3; Isaiah 58:5; Daniel 9:3).

Some of you may be wondering why Google decided to advertise themselves on their own platform. To we Gen X and Gen Y folk, Google is our daily bread. If you look back, most of us discovered Google on our own, when it first was released. It made everything way easier for us. No more forum searches, chat discussions, emails, and long web addresses, just to find a web page. Gen X and Gen Y had a great many questions, and we found our answers in Google.

Gen Z though, doesn't really use Google, because they don't use the web. They use apps, and a few apps at that. My children, all 5 of them, never think to use Google to answer their questions. They always call me or their mother, and then we have to Google it, because our children were never exposed to Google in a meaningful way. They see me use it daily, I'm a programmer, so I do mean DAILY; yet they never seem to grasp how powerful Google is, nor how to use it, despite how often I praise Google search.

( I use Brave search now, but you get the point.)

So, that is at least one of the reasons why Google is advertising.

Nice explanation of how search engines operate. But...

You only glossed over the key part, where Google will select what is most relevant to your search. The issue with Google today is that they have chosen a relevancy based on popularity.
Search for anything, and you get the most popular results first, regardless of how relevant they are to what you were actually after.

This is great for everyday use, but as a research tool, it limits the Internet quite a bit.

I use it daily to find answers to some very specific coding questions I have while working (I'm a full stack developer). Most of the time, you get good results, though you have to scroll down a bit to get past all those irrelevant but popular sites.
However, at least once a month I stumble on an issue that is very specific, and not matter how specific I make the search query, Google will just show me irrelevant results from popular pages. Even going through all the pages, no site can be found that has the answer.
Until you find some forum deep down in the results, often in a completely different language, where someone has stumbled on the same issue and someone else answered with a link to a site with the answer. That site wouldn't even show up in the Google results, because the site is not popular enough to fulfil Google's criteria for relevance.

Not sure if you read the book; I haven't. But, number of particles per dust sample is misleading for understanding how much dust is human skin. When they state percentage, we're thinking volume but the book is characterizing quantity. When we sweep or wipe up dust we are observing a volume of dust, which is affected by electrostatic interactions and volume of the particles themselves. I suspect that dead skin cells make up a very small portion of the volume of a given amount of dust, as the keratin will act to mediate electrostatic charge, allowing them to occupy a smaller space. Instead, dead skin will act like a glue, allowing higher densities of positive charged particles and settling them out. I believe the actual volume of skin cells in a sample of dust is a fraction of a percent, by virtue of the square cube law and looking at the quantity of larger particles. So, I think you have not really debunked the debunking as you have not addressed this aspect.

The law of conservation of mass says that the total mass of the inputs (dead skin cells, moisture from perspiration, oxygen from the air, etc.) and the total mass of the outputs (dead mites, mite poop, carbon dioxide produced by mite respiration, etc.) are related to standing mite biomass by difference: if inputs out mass outputs, standing mite biomass increases by the difference; if the reverse, it decreases by the difference; and if they are equal, it is unchanged. If you eat a pound of Doritos you will (transiently) gain more than a pound because the high salt content will cause the body to retain more water. Applying the law to a single favored input is illicit.

From my tests, dust inside my house is NOT from outside.  I have a ventilator system that has separate filters for intake air and output air.  Every time I clean the filters, the intake filters are completely clear - nothing is coming from outside.  But, the output filter is full of dust that originates from inside the house.  I have hardwood floors with almost no carpets except for the occasional scatter rugs.  Thus, my output "dust" is either coming from clothes,  or skin cells.  I am bald so nothing is coming from my hair.  Thus in my case, there is a large percentage of dead skin cells, which also account for all the dust that appears on bedsheets, and other clothing.  Next filter cleaning, I will check the dust with a microscope.  Excellent video, thanks.

It would depend wholly on where you are finding it.   In your belly button, or under your bedsheet, it's mostly skin.   In the air, it's much more likely to be pollen and other air borne particulates, a small percentage of them being skin.   Dead skin cells would probably settle out of the air faster though.    So if you are looking at surfaces outside, pollen would be the lion's share, inside, more human dust.

The skin shed in a bed over 10 years would only weigh 3Kg. "And by conservation of mass, the dust mites that feed off that dead skin could not weigh more than that."

This is such an obviously false statement, I'm very surprised that it's in this nit picky video. Just think of the other ways living things gain mass other than eating. The two obvious methods are drinking and respiration. Dust mites don't actually drink like we do, but they inhale water from the air. So in their respiration cycle they acquire the moisture they need from the humidity of the air.
If you look at the weight of dead skin cells in a mattress without dust mites this calculation is true. If you look at the total weight gained by a mattress with dust mites, you would be off by a factor of 2.
I'm not saying the mattress doubles in mass, but it's a lot more than the simple calculation provided.

People think a google search is 'research', but typical internet searches miss out on peer review, and they poorly assess the reputation of the author. Conflicting uneducated opinions rise to the top of a search if they are trendy or entertaining, not to mention the way corporate advertising plays a role, too. Even fact checking websites have been poisoned by emphasis of "cherry picked" information that supports an agenda. Add in controversy, conspiracy theories, and ulterior motives, and you've got a mess when trying to find objective information with a search engine. It's a reasonable place to start but never be too confident in your conclusions.

Google is both the source of information and misinformation. People just search what they already think they know about, so they are only validating their preconceived notions.
Currently, we are in a Pandemic, and there's been a mass confusion about whether or not to wear mask. People who believe they shouldn't wear mask will search things like "Does wearing a mask really help?" and then they will be lead to sites that promote their views, after which they will come to the conclusion that they should not wear mask.
So, this is how a lot of misinformation also spreads, and not just misinformation, a lot of stupid conspiracy theories also spread.
A lot of people believe Covid-19 is a hoax promoted by the new world order, and they will Google things like "Is Covid-19 real" and then, they will only look for sites that will validate their already held opinions.
And you will see a similar trend on social media, people will spread their misinformation, share those messages, and lead to a whole snowball of false information spreading around the social media.
You shouldn't jump to conclusions on everything you see or read on the internet, do your own research.

Dead skin cells often carry live bacteria that are part of the skin flora. If these bacteria can survive in dry conditions, as Staphylococci can, the skin cells being light and their flat shape allows them  to remain suspended in the air, airborne transmission of the live bacteria on them is very significant. Before we had increased number of air changes per hour and more efficient filtration in our hospitals, we had many surgical infections in hospitals due to these types of bacteria.

"Very well," he said. "But you still have not answered my question about where you are."
"Yes I did, remember? I told you how I got to where I am today: by hard work."
"Where are you?"
"What do you mean, where am I?"
"Where Are you?" he repeated softly.
"I'm here."
"Where is here?"
"In this office, in this gas station!" I was getting impatient with this game.
"Where is this gas station?"
"In Berkeley?"
"Where is Berkeley?"
"In California?"
"Where is California?"
"In the United States?"

"Where are the continents?
I sighed. "On the earth. Are we done yet?"
"Where is the earth?"
"In the solar system, third planet from the sun. The sun is a small star in the Milky Way galaxy, all right?"
"Where is the Milky Way?"
"Oh, brother, " I sighed impatiently, rolling my eyes. "In the universe." I sat back and crossed my arms with finality.
"And where," Socrates smiled, "is the universe?"
"The universe is well, there are theories about how it's shaped..."
"That's not what I asked. Where is it?"
"I don't know - how can I answer that?"
"That is the point. You cannot answer it, and you never will. There is no knowing about it. You are ignorant of where the universe is, and thus, where you are. In fact, you have no knowledge of where anything is or of What anything is or how is came to be. Life is a mystery.
"My ignorance is based on this understanding. Your understanding is based on ignorance. This is why I am a humorous fool, and you are a serious jackass.”

Saying that google's search is not a black box is kind of misleading, isn't it? Google probably uses machine learning (https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.wired.com/2016/02/ai-is-changing-the-technology-behind-google-searches/amp) in one way or the other. Therefore, they cannot totally understand what their algorithm actually does, since it works on probability and not causality (like machine learning in general). That is not a bad thing, but saying it is not a black box is like saying that you understand how someone makes decisions just be because you see, hear and smell what they smell (aka their "inputs").
(And yes, obviously it is more complicated than that. But nevertheless, there is a part that humans don't understand the reasoning of - that's what makes probabilistic stuff so great. Otherwise there would be no need for machine learning...)

This is not talked about enough so here I go. Humans shedding dust is not normal. We have natural oils which prevent that sort of thing from happening. The problem is soaps and frequent washing of our bodies, which leaves behind a dry body which sheds a lot more dust than it should.

Modern lifestyle makes it difficult to not shower or not use soaps because you'd smell like a human, which is obviously not acceptable. So, you can do the next best thing: get scented moisturizers which have chemicals that mimic natural human oils and apply it after washing your body with soap.

That way, you'll stop shedding a lot of the skin that you now do... and even the skin that you really shed, it will remain on your body until you shower the next day.

Derek, this is another facinating video. I do draw attention to the pronunciation of the sizes of dust particles. You have nailed it with millimeters (milly-meters), but "mi-crom-uh-ters" is incorrect. That is a measuring instrument used for extremely fine and accurate measurement of small objects. The smaller dust particles are measured in "micro-meters" and "nano-meters". You haven't said "nan-om-uh-ters" which would have been incorrect. All metric measurement units are pronounced as the prefix ahead of the unit "meters". "killo-meters", "milli-meters", "centi-meters", "nano-meters". A helpful link https://usma.org/correct-si-metric-usage#locale-notification

I could have told you we lose approximately 20m skins cells per hour right after you told me that the human body makes about 20m new skin cells per hour.  Is everyone constantly gaining weight?  Is your skin getting thicker or thinner over a span of years?  No.  Replacement and loss of cells obviously approaches equilibrium throughout most of an adult's life.  The loss has to closely approximate the gain.  Without seeing the end of the video, I can tell from experience that perhaps 90% of the dust in my immediate surroundings is shed skin cells.  Once you start paying attention to the process, it's clear that you're dumping dead skin into the air constantly.  The notion that "dust" means airborne particles is kinda dumb.  What's that white powder on my furniture that I wipe away?  "On furniture" and "airborne" are mutually exclusive.  There are other issues with the ideas in this video.  OK, samples were taken and examined -- that the collection methods were perfect, or even good-ish, cannot be established.  There's also an assertion about what ends up in your vaccuum cleaner, but is that dust?  Some of it is certainly human hair.  I don't think of hair as dust, do you?  Is a vaccuum cleaner a great sampling agent?  Seems to me that when I vaccuum, it collects plenty of stuff, but just blows some stuff around the room.  Ah, well, scholarship via Google is about as good as it sounds.

Before watching this: anyone who does laundry knows exactly where most dust comes from. Lint traps filling up after one or two loads of laundry should be a huge hint as to where most of it comes from, and why clothes become threadbare over time. Granted, I'm sure there's dead skin in there too, depending on how many bodies occupy a given area of space, but cloth is very non-resilient and is constantly shedding fibers that float around and settle. If you live in a city there will be soot. If you live in a suburban or rural area during the spring there will also be pollen. Year-round, though, it's fibers from blankets, shirts, pants, underwear, paper towels, napkins, carpets, etc...

this is fascinating to me because i am deathly allergic to dust. but not ALL dust. i cannot touch the inside of a computer or i go to the hospital. carpet gives me problems, but the biggest problem is vacuuming - i cannot touch any part of the stuff that gets vacuumed up or, again, i go to the hospital.

but i can dust my shelves okay, to an extent. and my bed, furniture, and clothes are fine for me. i can go into old abandoned houses and touch anything i want (so long as there's no machines like a computer... i can't touch those no matter where they exist - house, factory, office, outside, etc)

i used to work in the mailroom of a newspaper and it was full of paper dust everywhere. tons of it. i could touch it just fine... unless that paper dust existed inside of the machines and got blown out.

so it makes me wonder what in the dust, exactly, i am allergic to, because i am not allergic to all types of dust or dust that sits in certain areas. and this video didn't exactly answer my question, tho it was a great video, so i guess i am off to do some researching of my own and continue learning about dust make-up.

This is totally misleading. You have a range of dust particles from 0 to 2000 micrometers. You have a subrange 0-100 micrometers. This subrange makes 5% of all dust (roughly). Within these 5% skin makes um only 50%. So 5% * 50% = 2.5%. Skin makes up only 2.5% of all dust! Add another 20% from 100-200 range - you get 1%, 3.5% total.
This is a horrible calculation that i did, i know, it doesn't work that way. The point is that debunkers were NOT debunked with this video. Skin makes at most 10% of ALL dust (0-2000) range, if using the numbers provided by Derek.

A lot of comments on this video wondering, why would Google need to advertise? Didn't you ever notice that Coca-Cola still spends millions in advertising every year, despite the fact that you don't know of a single person who hasn't at least tried Coke at some point in their lives?

The answer is: Most advertising is not about selling a specific product; it's about keeping a positive brand image. Brand is so, so important for big companies that want to last. Sure, you use Google for search now. But what if another competitor springs up? The more you trust the brand, the less likely you are to even consider switching to another service. And then there's all their non-search products that you may be using. Maybe you'll choose an Android phone over an iPhone, because Google "feels" like a less evil corporation than Apple. Maybe you'll get a Chromebook?

And then there's potential future developments. Imagine you're a company that is developing future technologies that might be controversial, say, I don't know, driverless cars, or artificial intelligence. Then you'd want to maintain a high degree of public trust in your brand so you will have some advantage over your competitors when you launch those technologies. So you might try, for example, to present your company as trustworthy, one that takes truth and openness very seriously. Maybe you'd have a big information campaign about how some of your flagship technology works so that people associate your brand with openness and robust technology...

Hey Derek, I really missed the topic of size and count distribution of dust in your video. But since you taught me googling in this video , I did and found
"Particle Size Distribution in Domestic House Dust Samples-A comparison of the Characteristics of ISO Fine Test Dust versus Real House Dust(#868)"
Talking about percentages in the topic of dust, and others for example pm in exhaust engines, can be quite misleading. While in the upper source you can see a clear peak in dust-counts between 1 and 10 um the volumetric distribution shows that only around 50% is in the size range of skin dust particles, i.e. under 100 um. So if you brush together a huge chunk of dust, most of the volume will probably not be skin, but other matter. The graph with composition of dust over the particle radius was also not clear if it is talking about count/mass or volumetric composition, but maybe I missed smth.

*Dust mite diets and conservation of mass--dubious.*
About 11 minutes in, you indicate that dust mites can't account for the additional weight of a bed. While I don't dispute the conclusion, isn't your remark on the way to it sloppy and inaccurate? You briefly mention conservation of mass, but given your videos on weight gain and loss, you know it's more complicated than that. For example, if I eat a pound of donuts, is it true that I can't gain more than a pound from eating them? I don't know the details, but I imagine it involves considering how calories are stored as fat, fat contains water, and so the carbs from the donuts are converted to cells that contain water that could weigh more than the donuts I ate. Couldn't the dust mites gain more weigh than the skin cells they eat? They must intake moisture too. Anyway, perhaps a tad pedantic, but in the spirit of thinking more precisely, perhaps worth a footnote.

Nonetheless, another great video (with COVID haircut and all)!

You can't just dismiss the total weight of the dust mites (dead and living, plus dried dust mite feces) as less than total weight of dead skin cells, by "conservation of mass". This is almost certainly true, but the metabolism involves, oxygen, CO2, and water vapor, so the reactions are complex. And not only epidermis, but skin oils, sweat, and other bodily fluids.

It's complex.

At 11:00, you state that through conservation of mass, the dust mites that fed off that dead skin for ten years could not weigh more than the mass of skin cells available. I suggest that there is conservation of mass but the ten year old dust mites weigh more than the skin cells consumed because of respiration and growth.

Research tip I learned in college:
When I want to search something, I want to only look at official government sites (.gov websites) or educational institutions that have graduates and professors doing research (.edu websites). I don't care or want to read form blogs, any media source, or other unreliable source.

To do this, when I search a topic in Google, I use this simple trick. I usually end up doing a few Google searches to get a comprehensive review on something.

1. Go to Google, and in the search bar type want you want to know about.
Example: covid cases

2. BUT, here's the trick, add the following text after your search term, "site:"
Example: covid cases site:

3. Lastly, add the domain you want Google to search for (.gov, .edu).
Example: covid cases site:.gov
Example 2: covid cases site:.edu

This trick would work for other domains (like ".canada.ca" for official Canadian government pages), but I always will use .gov and .edu.

This is straight where all information comes from that is trickled into other platforms, so searching this way is the quickest and easiest way to get actual creditable sources

“Research,” used to mean, “Careful study of a given subject, field, or problem, undertaken to discover facts or principles.” I’m not aware of anyone redefining it to mean, “search again.”
Real research for a subject like this involves breaking out your instruments and measuring things for yourself, not just hunting the internet to find what others have said about the subject. It’s very sad if we think google is the definitive source for anything at all. Want to know what’s in house dust? Tell us what you think it is, then Grab a microscope, scoop up some dust, and look at it. Measure it. Test it. Show us, then explain your findings - don’t regurgitate to us what google says it is.
THAT is science. Googling is not science.

There's some horrifically bad math here. One pound per year is 10 pounds. Times 2 sleepers is 20 pounds. But the 10:47 time mark assertion is that only 6 pounds would accrete. Is there some unstated sleep period assumption, say 7 hours? And the "conservation of mass" argument that dust mites can't weigh more than that - um, hello? If you're counting the weight of the mites themselves after devouring, and assuming no other additions and subtractions (which is invalid anyway), then the mites GROW by 6 pounds. You add that to the mass of every mite that invades and dies in the "grip of" the mattress. Let's exaggerate to make the point: 100 pounds of mites devouring 6 pounds of mass can weigh more than 6 pounds.

I love the explanation of why knowledge is important. It echoes many of my college professors. But even more importantly, it opens the mind to consider what we're certain about or not. If only more people would question what we can be certain about, we'd have a lot less mess of false information to deal with. That is actually an open mind. And that's why I love this channel.

I wanted to point out that even certainty is relative to the level of knowledge we have about something. The more knowledge we gain about something as obvious as dust, the more we can understand just how amazingly interconnected everything in the world actually is. And from that, we can know our impact, or lack of it, with greater relative certainty.

The poetry of science is not merely the imagery of words or some metered scheme; it's the beauty of interconnected knowledge.

Your cuteness is a distraction. But your content does get through. However, please correct your wee glib comment that research is re-search. That of course may fit your Google-driven video here, but it does not serve either true research or knowledge of etymology.

"Research" has nothing to do with the prefix "re" as you suggested. The word derives from the Old French "recercher," meaning "seek out, search closely," from "re-", a prefix for intensity of action in this case, not repetition, + "cercher," "to seek for," which comes from the Latin "circare," "go about, wander," which connects with both "circle" and "circus." Research means "to look closely," not "to Google something already done.

Whoops, @9:50 you said that houses with wood floors have less dust than carpet. Which is actually false. - Carpets actually significantly reduce dust in houses by being a giant dust filter. - This is a common misconception that people think of carpet as a source of dust, when in fact it's a filter for dust. (Carpet has dust in it, but that's dust that's not in the air, because it's in the carpet - ironically many people with allergies also believe this myth and pull out their carpets, which in fact makes the air quality in their house get worse :/)

My process for scientific queries every time:
✔ Basic searches about hypotheses for the topic
✔ Finding scientific definitions for it, to look up ("define ____")
✔ Search Google Scholar to find relevant studies on the topic
✔ Read the criticisms of the studies by peers
❌Find subject experts for a nuanced overview of the topic or get pinpoints of what to look for next
❌Enhance understanding by reading the offline material specifically recommended by said experts
...
✔ Assume that the topic is too complicated or time-consuming for me to get a better answer than "I might have the right idea now, but I still don't really know"

What would be the total percent across all particle sizes? What is the distribution of particle sizes?

For example: if dust was made up of 50% small (0-100 μm), 35% medium (1-300 μm), and 15% large (+300 μm) dust particles, then dead skin being 50% of those small, 20% of those medium, and 10% of those large, would make up 25 + 7 + 1.5 = 33.5% of dust.

If the distribution was 75% small, 20% medium, and 5% large, then dead skin would make up 37.5 + 4 + 0.5 = 42% of dust. Dead skin would not be 50% of dust unless dust consisted almost entirely of small particles.

Very nice. Incredibly nit picking criticism. Conservation of mass doesn't ensure that the mass of dust bugs is the same as dead skin they eat. Dead skin cells are dessicated. A live bug will be mostly water. The dry mass of the bug will be limited by the mass of skin cells (and other food like spores and microbes) eaten. The question of where the dust bug gets its water from remains. The answer it appears is from the air. Dust mite populations and their ability to grow and reproduce is governed by the relative humidity. Once the RH goes above a critical value they can thrive. They seem to like periodic bouts of higher and lower humidity. Of course a human in a bed for the night is a great periodic source of local humidity.
None the less, one seriously doubts the assertions made about significant fractions of bedding being made of dust mites.

And the $64,000 question is: "Can human skin dust carry Coronavirus?"
Consider this; Coronavirus diameter is 0.1 um and dust particle can be up to 100 um diameter. Therefore, taking the ratio of the areas (yes, I know that's not a perfect analysis) you get about 1 million coronavirus spores per dust particle (rough estimate). Imagine inhaling several hundred thousand skin dust particles every minute of every day. That's a lot of coronavirus spores going down into the lowest parts of your lungs.

Old man story: back in 2011, I was interviewed for an IT job. The manager was unavailable and the program manager pulled his lead malware analyst to do my technical interview. Literally as we passed his desk. I am in no way a malware analyst. And he really didn't know what was involved in the job I was applying for. So he asked a lot of deep Windows questions that in retrospect, I'm proud I was able to answer as well as I did. But most of the answers I gave were "I'd Google it". And interestingly, that was the right answer. I didn't try to BS my way through, but explained that I knew how to find out what I needed to know quickly.
When I've interviewed applicants myself, I discuss searching with them. I ask them how they search and often give them examples to show me how they would go about getting the appropriate answer. Like you mention, asking what you think the answer is isn't always the correct approach. Sometimes asking a broader question gives you a better discussion. Of course asking too broad a question often gives you such an unfocused result, you never find your answer. Also, understanding the problem is required. I've seen so many people having a superficial understanding of the problem and spending days on the internet trying to find an answer.
Anyway... I don't work for Google. I'm an IT security guy with 35 years experience and have used a lot of search engines over the years. And effective use of search engines has made me successful!

Lol, wood chucks. Years ago, my oldest niece was speaking with family about how popular that particular little tongue twister had become at her high school. But there was a twist, you see back in my own high school days, I had taken it upon myself to write an answer to this little ditty. When I reminded her of this fact, and that what they were reciting was partially my creation, albeit a highly derivative one. They didn't want to believe me. And so off to google we went, to find that indeed the answer was nowhere to be seen on the internet. And so the full version, as I taught it my niece goes thusly:

How much wood, would a woodchuck, chuck, if a woodchuck could chuck wood?
A woodchuck, would chuck, as much wood, as a woodchuck could, if a woodchuck, could chuck wood.

Silly I know, but apparently many of the students found it amusing enough that it was being sung around campus all the time. Which really goes to show, that we can never really know how far our words reach out into the world. And as such, so too should we endeavor to make them words of which we can be proud. Unlike my silly little woodchuck answer.
